description: From Middle English eldmoder, from Old English eald mōdor (“grandmother”), equivalent to eld (“old”) +‎ mother. Cognate with Scots eldmoder, eldmother (“mother-in-law”), Old Frisian aldmōder, aldemōder (“grandmother”).

entries.meaning: (dialectal, now archaic) One's grandmother or other female ancestor, or one's mother-in-law.
examples: Item I gyve vnto my eldmother his wyffe my wyffes froke and a read petticote and a smoke.
